So funny. I have a distinct memory from probably the tenth grade. I actually had found one of these beetles in my back yard. I knew nothing about it, only that it was cool-looking. Nerdishly, I took it to school, and had it crawling on my desktop. A male classmate, being a total a-hole, took a book and slammed it down on my poor little pet, loud and hard. Any normal beetle would have been obliterated. My little friend showed no apparent damage, but lay motionless, presumably dead. A few minutes later, he was crawling around as if nothing had happened. Amazing to me, annoying to my felonious classmate.

Bit of a disclaimer, while yes it was recorded once that an Ironclad beetle got hit by a car and lived, that car was going very fast and probably was on a dirt road. It's pretty unlikely that the Ironclad beetle could survive a car rolling onto it and staying on it, nor would it fare well against being run over by a car on hard pavement. It's an impressive one-time local story, but it's not like any scientists have tried taking a bunch of beetles and running them over in scientific studies to prove it. Still, definitely the sturdiest bug that we know of, I know for a fact you can stomp as hard as you can on one of them with a boot and it can walk away unscathed.

uh, I got a bit confused with the snail picture while using arthropods as reference.
they're mollusks and have calcarean shells which differs from the chitin and ecdysis the members of arthropods have.
I think the intention was to show an unlikely animal that also have an "exoskeleton", but since some people still think snails are insects, it made me think maybe it could be clarified a little bit?
What about fleas? You can't squish them. At least not with your fingers. And you can hold one tightly for a couple minutes at least and it won't suffocate. It will leap away as soon as you let up.

I accidentally stood on a big longhorn beetle in my socked feet when changing out of my bike boots. I got quite a start when I saw what I'd stood on, at they aren't native here and it must have hatched out of imported wooden pallets. The floor was smooth concrete, and most of my weight went down before I recoiled (which probably pressed it even harder). It carried on strolling across the lab floor. Impressive: and that's without a fused elytra! :)

At school we had a 'spinney' (small wood) on the grounds that the biology classes used to teach about insects etc. I remember one lesson where we all rooted around looking for unfortunate insects to mount on pins after anaesthetising with ether. One lad was pleased to find a stag beetle. He dutifully put it in a cup with cottonwool and ether for the allotted time, and then managed to get a pin through it onto a display card. But then it woke up and just lifted the pin out and flew around the room crashing into things. They aren't very good at flying in any case, but you don't want one crashing into you with a pin sticking out of it! :)

4:33 cases are held by fasteners, sure, but blades are held in by "fir tree" splines. Ever heard of welding? Planes are Riveted because the rivets fail BEFORE the metal does. That is the point of not welding them together. A rivet will pop, but there is NO crack in the metal. This is by design.
